Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story:
I woke up early, the house already buzzing with the promise of laughter and the smell of cinnamon rolls. Today was our long-awaited family gathering, and as a grandmother, I knew how much my presence meant to everyone—especially the little ones who had been counting down the days. My daughter had called last night, reminding me, “Mom, don’t be late. The kids are so excited to see you.” I wanted nothing more than to be there, to listen to their stories and hold my newest grandchild.

But as I poured my coffee, I remembered the voting notice on the fridge. I’d misplaced my ID, and this morning was my only window to drive home and retrieve it before the polls closed tomorrow. Civic duty tugged at me; I’d always told my family how important it was to vote, to have a say. Yet, if I left now, I’d miss the start of the gathering, maybe even the group photo. My heart twisted, torn between being the grandmother my family expected and the responsible voter I believed I should be. I stood in the kitchen, keys in hand, wrestling with which part of myself to disappoint.
